retrieved_contexts:
EVA‐2311          LoRaWAN Temperature PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor

# NEW Features

- LoRaWAN wireless connectivity
- -70°C to 200°C temperature detection range
- IP67 for PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor
- Battery life up till 5 years@25°C, 15mins interval setting
- Easy to deploy and maintain

RoHS COMPLIANT 2002/95/EC

# Introduction

EVA-2311 is a LoRaWAN PT1000 round head probe sensor. The extended sensor itself has 2m length cable, IP67 rating design with -70°C to 200°C temperature detection range. It is capable to measure temperature at different kinds of applications, such as refrigerator, freezer, cooling pipe, etc. With its wide range, high penetration rate LoRa connectivity, the data transmission range can be up till hundred or thousand meters away. EVA-2311 can be installed directly on the walls, metal box or poles. EVA-2311 is powered by 2 AA 3.6v Li-ion batteries, battery life can up till 5 years based on certain conditions.

# Common Specification

# Temperature Sensor

| Measurement Range                                        | -70°C to 200°C                                        | | |
| -------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------- |---|---|
| Accuracy (Host and Sensor are in same environment)       | ±0.8°C between 0°C and 55°C                           | | |
| Accuracy (Host and Sensor are in different environments) | ±{(0.15 + 0.002\* |T2|)+1}°C between -70°C and 0°C    |
|                                                          | ±{(0.15 + 0.002\* |T2|)+0.6}°C between 55°C and 200°C |

All product specifications are subject to change without notice. Last updated: 19-Apr-2024

# Ordering Information

| LoRaWAN Temperature and Humidity Sensor |                                                                       |
| --------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| EVA-2311-NA                             | LoRaWAN Temperature PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor - US 902-928 (MHz) |
| EVA-2311-EA                             | LoRaWAN Temperature PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor - EU 863-870 (MHz) |
| EVA-2311-TA                             | LoRaWAN Temperature PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor - AS 919-924 (MHz) |
| EVA-2311-ZA                             | LoRaWAN Temperature PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor - AU 915-928 (MHz) |

# LoRaWAN Gateway

# Common Specification

| Wireless Communication |                                                                           | Probe Dimension | 5 x 30 mm           |
| ---------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------- | ------------------- |
| Frequency Band         | EU 863-870 (MHz) / US 902-928 (MHz) / AU 915-928 (MHz) / AS 919-924 (MHz) | IP Class        | IP67                |
| Spreading Factor       | 7\~12                                                                     | Wire Length     | 2000 mm             |
| Transmit Power         | Up to 20dBm                                                               | Topology        | Star (LoRa/LoRaWAN) |
| Sensitivity            | -148dB                                                                    |                 |                     |

# Ordering Information

The measuring point for the nominal resistance is 2 mm from the end of the sensor body.

# Temperature Range of Tolerance Class

Validity of Class F 0.3 (B) -50 °C to +150 °C

The specified tolerance classes refer to continuous operation.

Short term temperature exposure for soldering: Max. 5 minutes up to 250 °C.

# Dimensions and Tolerances in mm

| L:  | 2.1 -0.2/+0.2  |
| --- | -------------- |
| W1: | 1.9 +0.2       |
| H:  | 0.8 -0.2/+0.25 |
| LL: | 7±1            |
| Lø: | 0.22 ±0.02     |
| W2: | 0.7 ±0.1       |

# Response Time

Air (v = 3 m/s): t0.5 = 1.5 s

t0.9 = 5 s

# Measuring Current

Pt100 Ω: 0.3 to 1 mA

Pt1000 Ω: 0.1 to 0.3 mA (self-heating has to be considered)

Color, shape and forming of fixing drop may vary

- LoRaWAN wireless connectivity
- -70°C to 200°C temperature detection range
- IP67 for PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor
- Battery life up till 5 years@25°C, 15mins interval setting
- Easy to deploy and maintain

RoHS COMPLIANT 2002/95/EC

# Introduction

EVA-2311 is a LoRaWAN PT1000 round head probe sensor. The extended sensor itself has 2m length cable, IP67 rating design with -70°C to 200°C temperature detection range. It is capable to measure temperature at different kinds of applications, such as refrigerator, freezer, cooling pipe, etc. With its wide range, high penetration rate LoRa connectivity, the data transmission range can be up till hundred or thousand meters away. EVA-2311 can be installed directly on the walls, metal box or poles. EVA-2311 is powered by 2 AA 3.6v Li-ion batteries, battery life can up till 5 years based on certain conditions.

# Common Specification

|                                                          | ±{(0.15 + 0.002\* |T2|)+0.6}°C between 55°C and 200°C |

detailed_results.question: How is the Advantech EVA-2311 sensor configured?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
The Advantech EVA-2311 sensor is configured using Modbus settings. Here are the key configuration details:

1. **COMs Settings**:
   - **Sensor Address**: 
     - 40601: Baud Rate (Options: 0 = 9.6k, 1 = 19.2k, 2 = 38.4k; Default: 1)
     - 40602: Parity (Options: 0 = None, 1 = Odd, 2 = Even; Default: 0)

2. **Sensor Data - Read Only**:
   - The sensor provides data through specific Modbus registers:
     - **40001**: Humidity (%RH) - Range: 0 to 100% (Min: 0, Max: 10000)
     - **40002**: Temperature (°C) - Range: -1638.4 to 1638.3
     - **40003**: Temperature (°F) - Range: -1638.4 to 1638.3
     - **40004**: Dew Point (°C)
     - **40005**: Dew Point (°F)

3. **Data Calculation**:
   - The temperature is calculated using the formula: (Modbus register value) ÷ 20.
   - The humidity is calculated as: (Holding register value) ÷ 100.
   - The dew point is calculated as: (Holding register value) ÷ 100.

These settings allow for the configuration and retrieval of data from the EVA-2311 sensor, ensuring accurate monitoring of temperature and humidity.
detailed_results.ground_truth: Configuration of the Advantech EVA-2311 is done via wireless downlink commands.
detailed_results.expected_response: The Advantech EVA-2311 is configured using wireless downlink commands.
expected_contexts: Configuration Interface: Wireless downlink commands
Wireless Communication: LoRaWAN
LED Indicator: Power on, TX, reset to default
Spreading Factor: 7-12
The data transmission range can up till hundred or thousand meters away.

# Introduction

EVA-2311 is a LoRaWAN PT1000 round head probe sensor. The extended sensor itself has 2m length cable, IP67 rating design with -70°C to 200°C temperature detection range. It is capable to measure temperature at different kinds of applications, such as refrigerator, freezer, cooling pipe, etc. With its wide range, high penetration rate LoRa connectivity, the data transmission range can be up till hundred or thousand meters away. EVA-2311 can be installed directly on the walls, metal box or poles. EVA-2311 is powered by 2 AA 3.6v Li-ion batteries, battery life can up till 5 years based on certain conditions.

Temperature range -50 °C to +150 °C

Designed for low temperature applications

Optimized for soldering connection

High accuracy and interchangeability

Excellent long term stability and low drift

LS series Pt-RTDs are designed for high volume low temperature applications where long term stability, interchangeability and accuracy are vital. Typical applications include HVAC, Food and Beverage, Medical and Industrial equipment.

retrieved_contexts:
PJ85775
# ±0.5ᵒC Digital Temperature Sensor with Digital Interface

# In a SOP8/MSOP-8 Package

# GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor with ±0.5 °C accuracy. Temperature data can be read out directly via digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C or 2-wire) by MCU, Bluetooth Chip or SoC chip.

# FEATURES

- Operation Voltage: 1.75 V to 5.5 V
- Average Quiescent Current: 3.0 uA (Typ.) at 1.0 con/s
- Standby Current: 1.0 uA (Typ.)
- Temperature Accuracy without calibration:
- ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C
- ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C
- ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C
- 12 bit ADC for 0.0625 °C resolution
- Compatible with SMBus, 2-wire and I²C interface
- Compatible industry LM75 with performance improved
- Programmable Over/Under Temperature
- Programmable Active Low or High for ALERT pin
- Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
- Generate 32 different slave address by setup A0, A1, A2 pin
- Temperature Range: -40 °C to 125 °C

PJ85775
# ±0.5ᵒC Digital Temperature Sensor with Digital Interface

# In a SOP8/MSOP-8 Package

# GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor with ±0.5 °C accuracy. Temperature data can be read out directly via digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C or 2-wire) by MCU, Bluetooth Chip or SoC chip.

# FEATURES

- Operation Voltage: 1.75 V to 5.5 V
- Average Quiescent Current: 3.0 uA (Typ.) at 1.0 con/s
- Standby Current: 1.0 uA (Typ.)
- Temperature Accuracy without calibration:
- ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C
- ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C
- ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C
- 12 bit ADC for 0.0625 °C resolution
- Compatible with SMBus, 2-wire and I²C interface
- Compatible industry LM75 with performance improved
- Programmable Over/Under Temperature
- Programmable Active Low or High for ALERT pin
- Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
- Generate 32 different slave address by setup A0, A1, A2 pin
- Temperature Range: -40 °C to 125 °C

# APPLICATIONS

# Common Specification

| Wireless Communication |                                                                           | Probe Dimension | 5 x 30 mm           |
| ---------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------- | ------------------- |
| Frequency Band         | EU 863-870 (MHz) / US 902-928 (MHz) / AU 915-928 (MHz) / AS 919-924 (MHz) | IP Class        | IP67                |
| Spreading Factor       | 7\~12                                                                     | Wire Length     | 2000 mm             |
| Transmit Power         | Up to 20dBm                                                               | Topology        | Star (LoRa/LoRaWAN) |
| Sensitivity            | -148dB                                                                    |                 |                     |

# Ordering Information

S15S Temperature and Humidity Sensor

# Features

The Temperature and Temperature/Humidity Sensor works in a variety of environments to provide temperature and humidity measurements.

- Connects via RS485 Modbus® registers
- Rugged overmolded design
- Ships with aluminum grill filter cap
- Optional stainless steel 10 μm sintered filter available separately

detailed_results.question: Can the PANJIT PJ85775 be used as a standalone thermostat?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
The PANJIT PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor designed to provide temperature readings via a digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C, or 2-wire). While it can measure temperature accurately and has features such as programmable over/under temperature alerts, it does not function as a standalone thermostat on its own. 

To use the PJ85775 as part of a thermostat system, it would need to be integrated with a microcontroller (MCU) or a similar device that can process the temperature data and control heating or cooling systems based on that data. Therefore, while it can be a component in a thermostat system, it cannot operate independently as a thermostat.
detailed_results.ground_truth: Yes, the PANJIT PJ85775 is capable of functioning as a standalone thermostat.
detailed_results.expected_response: Yes, the PANJIT PJ85775 can be used as a standalone thermostat.
expected_contexts: PJ85775 can be used as standalone thermostat.
Standalone Thermostat: PJ85775 can also be used as standalone thermostat shown as below.
It has ALERT logic output pin with open drain structure...
APPLICATIONS: Smart HVAC System
The trigger temperature and hysteresis temperature can be setup in factory before shipping to customer.

Do not leave this pins open.

detailed_results.question: What is the purpose of the ALERT pin on the PANJIT PJ85775?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The ALERT pin on the PANJIT PJ85775 is used to indicate when the temperature has crossed a programmable over or under temperature threshold. It can be configured to be active low or high, allowing the device to signal to the connected microcontroller or system that a temperature condition requiring attention has been detected. This feature is useful for applications that need to monitor temperature and respond to specific conditions, such as triggering alarms or initiating cooling or heating processes.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The ALERT pin on the PJ85775 signals when temperature exceeds programmed limits.
detailed_results.expected_response: The ALERT pin on the PANJIT PJ85775 is an open-drain output used to indicate an alert when the measured temperature goes over or under the user-programmed high and low temperature limits.
expected_contexts: It has ALERT logic output pin with open drain structure, which is selectable for active low or high by programming.
FUNCTIONAL PIN DESCRIPTION: ALERT: To Indicate ALERT of over or under Temperature programmed by setting THIGH/TLOW register...
ALERT Output: ALERT pin is output with open drain...
ALERT response is compatible with SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA).
If the measured temperature meets or exceeds the high-limit temperature, ALERT pin will be asserted.

detailed_results.question: What is the maximum I2C communication speed supported by the PJ85775?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The PJ85775 supports I²C communication, but the maximum I²C communication speed is not explicitly mentioned in the provided excerpts. Typically, standard I²C communication speeds are 100 kHz for standard mode and up to 400 kHz for fast mode. For specific details regarding the maximum speed supported by the PJ85775, it would be best to refer to the official datasheet or technical documentation from the manufacturer.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The PJ85775 supports I2C communication up to 400 kHz.
detailed_results.expected_response: The PANJIT PJ85775 supports I2C communication with speeds up to 400 kHz (Fast Mode).
expected_contexts: PJ85775 supports I²C communication with speed up to 400 kHz.
ELECTRICAL CHARACTERISTICS: fCLK SCL frequency Fast Mode MAX 400 KHz
The chip is compatible with both SMBus and I2C.
This chip supports I2C fast mode (400kHz) and standard mode (100kHz).
If the master needs to run at frequencies above 400 kHz in I2C, the master device must issue an HS-mode master code.

detailed_results.question: What are the default high and low temperature alert limits for the PANJIT PJ85775?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The default high and low temperature alert limits for the PANJIT PJ85775 are not explicitly stated in the provided excerpts. However, the PJ85775 features programmable over/under temperature alerts, which means that the user can set these limits according to their specific requirements. The temperature range for the PJ85775 is from -40 °C to 125 °C, and the accuracy is ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C, ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C, and ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C. For specific default values, you may need to refer to the manufacturer's documentation or datasheet.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The default alert limits for the PJ85775 are 75°C (low) and 80°C (high).
detailed_results.expected_response: The default low-temperature limit for the PANJIT PJ85775 is 75°C (0x4B00), and the default high-temperature limit is 80°C (0x5000).
expected_contexts: Low_Temp_Set, Setup Low Temperature Limitation register: Default Data: 0x4B (1st Byte) 0x00 (2nd Byte)... which means 75°C.
High_Temp_Set, Setup High Temperature Limitation register: Default Data: 0x50 (1st Byte) 0x00 (2nd Byte)... which means 80°C.
Register Map: 0x02 Low_Temp_Set... Default Data 0x4B00
Register Map: 0x03 High_Temp_Set... Default Data 0x5000
The chip compares Temp_Data [0x00] register and High_Temp_Set register [0x03]/Low_Temp_Set register [0x02] in each conversion cycle.

If you have access to that documentation, it would provide the necessary information regarding the 'EM' bit and its role in the sensor's operation.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The 'EM' bit in the PJ85775 selects between 12-bit and 13-bit temperature data formats.

# ±0.5ᵒC Digital Temperature Sensor with Digital Interface

# In a SOP8/MSOP-8 Package

# GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor with ±0.5 °C accuracy. Temperature data can be read out directly via digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C or 2-wire) by MCU, Bluetooth Chip or SoC chip.

# FEATURES

- Operation Voltage: 1.75 V to 5.5 V
- Average Quiescent Current: 3.0 uA (Typ.) at 1.0 con/s
- Standby Current: 1.0 uA (Typ.)
- Temperature Accuracy without calibration:
- ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C
- ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C
- ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C
- 12 bit ADC for 0.0625 °C resolution
- Compatible with SMBus, 2-wire and I²C interface
- Compatible industry LM75 with performance improved
- Programmable Over/Under Temperature
- Programmable Active Low or High for ALERT pin
- Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
- Generate 32 different slave address by setup A0, A1, A2 pin
- Temperature Range: -40 °C to 125 °C

# APPLICATIONS

detailed_results.generated_answer: The PANJIT PJ85775 does not explicitly list selectable temperature conversion rates in the provided excerpts. However, it mentions an "Average Quiescent Current" of 3.0 µA (Typ.) at 1.0 conversion per second (con/s). This implies that the sensor can operate at a conversion rate of 1.0 con/s, but additional rates are not specified in the excerpts. For detailed information on selectable conversion rates, it would be best to refer to the full datasheet or technical documentation for the PJ85775.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The selectable conversion rates for the PJ85775 are 8.0Hz, 4.0Hz, 1.0Hz, and 0.25Hz.
detailed_results.expected_response: The four selectable temperature conversion rates for the PANJIT PJ85775 are 8.0Hz, 4.0Hz, 1.0Hz, and 0.25Hz.
expected_contexts: CR1, CR0, Conversion Rate Selection bits: These 2 bits allow user to setup different conversion rate for temperature.
Conversion Rate Table: 00: 8.0Hz / 0.125s (default), 01: 4.0Hz / 0.25s, 10: 1.0Hz / 1.0s, 11: 0.25Hz / 4.0s.
Config, Configuration Setup register: CR1, CR0
The default is 00 after POR, meaning the conversion rate is 8Hz.
This feature is used for reducing power consumption when continuous temperature monitoring is not necessary.

detailed_results.question: How does the 'Fault Queue' feature of the PJ85775 work?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
The 'Fault Queue' feature of the PJ85775 allows the sensor to manage temperature alerts more effectively by storing multiple temperature readings before triggering an alert. This feature helps to prevent false alarms caused by transient temperature fluctuations.

When the temperature exceeds or falls below the programmed thresholds, the sensor can queue up to a certain number of fault conditions (typically configurable). The sensor will only assert the ALERT pin after a specified number of consecutive fault conditions have been detected, thus ensuring that only persistent temperature changes trigger an alert. This feature is particularly useful in applications where brief temperature spikes or dips may occur but do not represent a true fault condition.

The specifics of how many faults can be queued and the exact configuration options would typically be detailed in the device's datasheet or technical documentation.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The PJ85775's 'Fault Queue' requires a set number of consecutive temperature faults (1, 2, 4, or 6) before triggering an alert.
detailed_results.expected_response: The 'Fault Queue' feature of the PANJIT PJ85775 allows the user to set the number of consecutive fault conditions (1, 2, 4, or 6) that must occur before the ALERT pin is triggered, which helps to prevent false alerts from noise.
expected_contexts: F1, F0, Fault Queue bits: These 2 bits are used to setup the number of fault conditions to trigger alert.
This feature is used to prevent a false alert, which is immune to certain noise in application.
Fault Queue Number Table: 00: 1 (default), 01: 2, 10: 4, 11: 6.
The default is 00 after POR, which means one time fault.
The ALERT pin will becomes active if the monitored temperature equals or exceeds the value setup...for a consecutive number of faults according to setup by F1 and F0 bits.

detailed_results.question: What is the difference between Comparator Mode and Interrupt Mode for the PJ85775's ALERT pin?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
The PJ85775's ALERT pin can operate in two modes: Comparator Mode and Interrupt Mode. 

1. **Comparator Mode**: In this mode, the ALERT pin is used to signal when the temperature exceeds or falls below the programmed over/under temperature thresholds. The pin will change its state (active low or high) based on the temperature readings compared to the set thresholds. This mode continuously monitors the temperature and provides a real-time indication of whether the temperature is within the acceptable range.

2. **Interrupt Mode**: In this mode, the ALERT pin functions as an interrupt signal. It is triggered only when the temperature crosses the set thresholds, generating a one-time alert. This mode is useful for applications where the microcontroller or processor can enter a low-power state and only wake up when an alert is generated, thus conserving energy.

In summary, Comparator Mode provides continuous monitoring and alerts based on temperature changes, while Interrupt Mode generates alerts only when specific temperature thresholds are crossed, allowing for more efficient power management.
detailed_results.ground_truth: In Comparator Mode, the PJ85775's ALERT pin follows the temperature relative to high/low limits, while in Interrupt Mode it latches until cleared by a read command.
detailed_results.expected_response: In Comparator Mode, the ALERT pin stays active as long as the temperature is above the high limit and deactivates only when it drops below the low limit. In Interrupt Mode, the ALERT pin becomes active when the high limit is exceeded and stays active until it is cleared by a read operation or an SMBus Alert Response.
expected_contexts: ALTM, Alert Operation Mode bit: This bit allows user to select ALERT pin operation mode: Comparator Mode or Interrupt Mode.
Comparator mode (ALTM=0): The ALERT pin keeps active until the temperature falls below the value setup in Low_Temp_Set [0x02] register.
Interrupt mode (ALTM=1): The ALERT pin keeps active until a read operation of any register happens or the chip responds to SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA) successfully.
The default is 0 after POR to select Comparator Mode.
When ALERT pin is cleared (in interrupt mode), it will become active again only when the temperature falls below the value setup in Low_Temp_Set register.

detailed_results.question: Does the PANJIT PJ85775 sensor support the SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA)?
detailed_results.generated_answer: Yes, the PANJIT PJ85775 sensor supports the SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA).
detailed_results.ground_truth: Yes, the PJ85775 supports SMBus ARA in interrupt mode.
detailed_results.expected_response: Yes, the PANJIT PJ85775 supports the SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA) feature when operating in interrupt mode (ALTM=1).
expected_contexts: Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
ALERT response is compatible with SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA).
SMBus Alert Response Address (ARA): The chip supports the SMBus alert function feature.
When the master detects that the ALERT pin is asserted, it will send Alert Response Address (ARA) to general address (0001, 1001b).
If the chip wins the arbitration, ALERT pin is released after completion of SMBus ARA command.

# ±0.5ᵒC Digital Temperature Sensor with Digital Interface

# In a SOP8/MSOP-8 Package

# GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor with ±0.5 °C accuracy. Temperature data can be read out directly via digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C or 2-wire) by MCU, Bluetooth Chip or SoC chip.

# FEATURES

- Operation Voltage: 1.75 V to 5.5 V
- Average Quiescent Current: 3.0 uA (Typ.) at 1.0 con/s
- Standby Current: 1.0 uA (Typ.)
- Temperature Accuracy without calibration:
- ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C
- ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C
- ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C
- 12 bit ADC for 0.0625 °C resolution
- Compatible with SMBus, 2-wire and I²C interface
- Compatible industry LM75 with performance improved
- Programmable Over/Under Temperature
- Programmable Active Low or High for ALERT pin
- Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
- Generate 32 different slave address by setup A0, A1, A2 pin
- Temperature Range: -40 °C to 125 °C

detailed_results.question: What does the 'OS' (One Shot) bit do in the PJ85775 configuration?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The 'OS' (One Shot) bit in the PJ85775 configuration is used to control the operation mode of the temperature sensor. When the OS bit is set, the sensor performs a single temperature measurement and then goes into a low-power mode, rather than continuously measuring temperature. This is useful for applications where power conservation is important, as it allows the sensor to take a measurement only when needed, rather than continuously consuming power while monitoring temperature.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The 'OS' bit in the PJ85775 initiates a single temperature measurement from shutdown mode.
detailed_results.expected_response: When the PANJIT PJ85775 is in shutdown mode, setting the 'OS' (One Shot) bit to '1' triggers a single temperature conversion, after which the device returns to shutdown mode to conserve power.
expected_contexts: OS, One shot Conversion bit: When the device is in shutdown mode, setting this bit as '1' will trigger a single time temperature conversion.
The device returns to shutdown mode once it completes the single conversion.
This feature is used for reducing power consumption when continuous temperature monitoring is not necessary.
During the conversion, the OS bit reads as '0'.
Config, Configuration Setup register: OS

PJ85775
# ±0.5ᵒC Digital Temperature Sensor with Digital Interface

# In a SOP8/MSOP-8 Package

# GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor with ±0.5 °C accuracy. Temperature data can be read out directly via digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C or 2-wire) by MCU, Bluetooth Chip or SoC chip.

# FEATURES

- Operation Voltage: 1.75 V to 5.5 V
- Average Quiescent Current: 3.0 uA (Typ.) at 1.0 con/s
- Standby Current: 1.0 uA (Typ.)
- Temperature Accuracy without calibration:
- ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C
- ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C
- ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C
- 12 bit ADC for 0.0625 °C resolution
- Compatible with SMBus, 2-wire and I²C interface
- Compatible industry LM75 with performance improved
- Programmable Over/Under Temperature
- Programmable Active Low or High for ALERT pin
- Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
- Generate 32 different slave address by setup A0, A1, A2 pin
- Temperature Range: -40 °C to 125 °C

# APPLICATIONS

# Common Specification

| Wireless Communication |                                                                           | Probe Dimension | 5 x 30 mm           |

| Frequency Band         | EU 863-870 (MHz) / US 902-928 (MHz) / AU 915-928 (MHz) / AS 919-924 (MHz) | IP Class        | IP67                |

| Sensitivity            | -148dB                                                                    |                 |                     |

PJ85775
# ±0.5ᵒC Digital Temperature Sensor with Digital Interface

# In a SOP8/MSOP-8 Package

# GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor with ±0.5 °C accuracy. Temperature data can be read out directly via digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C or 2-wire) by MCU, Bluetooth Chip or SoC chip.

# FEATURES

- Operation Voltage: 1.75 V to 5.5 V
- Average Quiescent Current: 3.0 uA (Typ.) at 1.0 con/s
- Standby Current: 1.0 uA (Typ.)
- Temperature Accuracy without calibration:
- ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C
- ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C
- ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C
- 12 bit ADC for 0.0625 °C resolution
- Compatible with SMBus, 2-wire and I²C interface
- Compatible industry LM75 with performance improved
- Programmable Over/Under Temperature
- Programmable Active Low or High for ALERT pin
- Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
- Generate 32 different slave address by setup A0, A1, A2 pin
- Temperature Range: -40 °C to 125 °C

# APPLICATIONS

PJ85775
# ±0.5ᵒC Digital Temperature Sensor with Digital Interface

# In a SOP8/MSOP-8 Package

# GENERAL DESCRIPTION

The PJ85775 is a digital temperature sensor with ±0.5 °C accuracy. Temperature data can be read out directly via digital interface (compatible with SMBus, I²C or 2-wire) by MCU, Bluetooth Chip or SoC chip.

# FEATURES

- Operation Voltage: 1.75 V to 5.5 V
- Average Quiescent Current: 3.0 uA (Typ.) at 1.0 con/s
- Standby Current: 1.0 uA (Typ.)
- Temperature Accuracy without calibration:
- ±0.5 °C from 0 °C to 50 °C
- ±1.0 °C from -20 °C to 85 °C
- ±1.5 °C from -40 °C to 125 °C
- 12 bit ADC for 0.0625 °C resolution
- Compatible with SMBus, 2-wire and I²C interface
- Compatible industry LM75 with performance improved
- Programmable Over/Under Temperature
- Programmable Active Low or High for ALERT pin
- Support SMBus ALERT Response Address (ARA)
- Generate 32 different slave address by setup A0, A1, A2 pin
- Temperature Range: -40 °C to 125 °C

# APPLICATIONS

| 40001          | Humidity (%RH)   | Min Value: 0 Max Value: 100% | Min (Dec): 0 Max (Dec): 10000 |

| 40003          | Temperature (°F) | -1638.4 to 1638.3            | -32768 to 32767               |
| 40004          | Dew Point (°C)   |                              |                               |
| 40005          | Dew Point (°F)   |                              |                               |

The temperature = (Modbus register value) ÷ 20. The humidity = (Holding register value) ÷ 100. The dew point = (Holding register value) ÷ 100.

EVA‐2311          LoRaWAN Temperature PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor

# NEW Features

- LoRaWAN wireless connectivity
- -70°C to 200°C temperature detection range
- IP67 for PT1000 Round Head Probe Sensor
- Battery life up till 5 years@25°C, 15mins interval setting
- Easy to deploy and maintain

RoHS COMPLIANT 2002/95/EC

# Introduction

EVA-2311 is a LoRaWAN PT1000 round head probe sensor. The extended sensor itself has 2m length cable, IP67 rating design with -70°C to 200°C temperature detection range. It is capable to measure temperature at different kinds of applications, such as refrigerator, freezer, cooling pipe, etc. With its wide range, high penetration rate LoRa connectivity, the data transmission range can be up till hundred or thousand meters away. EVA-2311 can be installed directly on the walls, metal box or poles. EVA-2311 is powered by 2 AA 3.6v Li-ion batteries, battery life can up till 5 years based on certain conditions.

# Configuration Instructions

# SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software

Banner's SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software offers an easy way to configure and demonstrate Banner Modbus devices. Users have full control of device configuration, the ability to visualize device data, and to demonstrate device features. The easy-to-use software provides a variety of tools and works with Banner Modbus devices.

- Allows for the configuration and demo of Banner Modbus devices
- Free to download and available on the Banner website at https://www.bannerengineering.com/sg/en/products/software/snap-signal-configuration-software.html
- Works on Microsoft® Windows® 7 and 10(1)
- BWA-UCT-900 cable required to connect PC-based SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software to Banner Modbus devices

# S15S Modbus Configuration

# Sensor Data - Read Only

# S15S Modbus Configuration

| 40003          | Temperature (°F) | -1638.4 to 1638.3            | -32768 to 32767               |
| 40004          | Dew Point (°C)   |                              |                               |
| 40005          | Dew Point (°F)   |                              |                               |

The Temperature and Temperature/Humidity Sensor works in a variety of environments to provide temperature and humidity measurements.

detailed_results.question: What do the LED indicators on the Banner S15S signify?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The provided excerpts do not contain specific information about the LED indicators on the Banner S15S. To find out what the LED indicators signify, you may need to refer to the product manual or technical documentation for the S15S Temperature and Humidity Sensor, which typically includes details about LED functions and their meanings.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The Banner S15S has LEDs for Power (Green), Modbus Communication (Amber), and Sensor Measurement (Amber).
detailed_results.expected_response: On the Banner S15S, a solid green LED indicates power is on, a flashing amber LED indicates active Modbus communication, and another amber LED flashes every five seconds to indicate a sensor measurement is being taken.
expected_contexts: Status Indicators: Power LED Indicator (Green) Solid Green = Power On
Status Indicators: Modbus Communication LED Indicator (Amber LED 1) Flashing Amber = Modbus communications are active
Status Indicators: Sensor Measurement LED Indicator (Amber LED 2) Flashes every five seconds
Indicators: Green LED: Power, Amber LED 1 (Flashing): Modbus communications active, Amber LED 2 (Flashing Every 5 Seconds): Sensor measurement LED indicator
Off = Power Off / Modbus communications are not present

detailed_results.question: How can the factory configuration of the Banner S15S be restored?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
To restore the factory configuration of the Banner S15S, you would typically use the SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software. This software allows users to configure and demonstrate Banner Modbus devices, including restoring factory settings. Here are the general steps you might follow:

1. **Download and Install SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software**: Ensure you have the software installed on your PC. It is available for free on the Banner website.

2. **Connect the Device**: Use the BWA-UCT-900 cable to connect your PC to the Banner S15S device.

3. **Open the Software**: Launch the SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software on your PC.

4. **Select the Device**: In the software, select the S15S device you want to configure.

5. **Restore Factory Settings**: Look for an option to restore factory settings or default configuration within the software. This option may be found under a settings or configuration menu.

6. **Confirm the Action**: Follow any prompts to confirm that you want to restore the factory settings.

7. **Disconnect and Test**: Once the factory settings have been restored, disconnect the device and test it to ensure it is functioning as expected.

For specific instructions, refer to the user manual or documentation provided with the SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software or the S15S device.
detailed_results.ground_truth: To restore the Banner S15S to factory settings, write '1' to Modbus address 40605.

detailed_results.question: What types of gases can the Bosch BME690 sensor detect?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The Bosch BME690 sensor is designed to detect various gases, including volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and other air quality-related gases. However, the specific types of gases it can detect are not detailed in the provided excerpts. For precise information on the gas detection capabilities of the BME690 sensor, it would be best to refer to the complete datasheet or product documentation from Bosch Sensortec.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The Bosch BME690 can detect VOCs, VSCs, carbon monoxide, and hydrogen.
detailed_results.expected_response: The Bosch BME690 gas sensor can detect Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), volatile sulfur compounds (VSCs), and other gases like carbon monoxide and hydrogen.
expected_contexts: The gas sensor can detect Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), volatile sulfur compounds (VSCs) and other gases such as carbon monoxide and hydrogen.
The BME690 is a metal oxide-based sensor that detects gases by adsorption... The BME690 reacts to most volatile compounds.
The BME690 is capable of measuring the sum of VOCs/contaminants in the surrounding air.
In standard configuration, the presence of VSCs is being detected as indicator for e.g. bacteria growth.
Bad breath or spoiled food detection based on the measurement of volatile sulfur compounds, which are an indicator of bacteria growth.

detailed_results.question: What digital interfaces does the Bosch BME690 support?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The Bosch BME690 supports digital interfaces, but the specific interfaces are not mentioned in the provided excerpts. Therefore, I cannot provide the exact digital interfaces supported by the BME690 based on the given information.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The Bosch BME690 supports I2C and SPI (3 and 4 wire) interfaces.
detailed_results.expected_response: The Bosch BME690 supports both I2C (up to 3.4 MHz) and SPI (3 and 4 wire, up to 10 MHz) digital interfaces.
expected_contexts: Key features: Digital interface: I2C (up to 3.4 MHz) and SPI (3 and 4 wire, up to 10 MHz)
The sensor supports the I2C and SPI digital interfaces, where it acts as a slave for both protocols.
The I2C interface supports the Standard, Fast and High Speed modes.
The SPI interface supports both SPI mode '00' and mode '11' in 4-wire and 3-wire configuration.
Interface selection is done automatically based on CSB (chip select) status.

detailed_results.question: What are some of the key outputs provided by the BSEC software for the BME690?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
The BSEC (Bosch Software Environmental Cluster) software for the BME690 provides several key outputs, including:

1. **Temperature**: The software calculates and outputs the temperature readings based on sensor data.
2. **Humidity**: It provides humidity levels as measured by the sensor.
3. **Pressure**: The software outputs atmospheric pressure readings.
4. **Gas Resistance**: It measures and outputs the resistance of the gas sensor, which can be used to infer air quality.
5. **Dew Point**: The software calculates and outputs the dew point based on temperature and humidity readings.
6. **IAQ (Indoor Air Quality) Index**: It may provide an index or score indicating the quality of indoor air based on various sensor readings.

These outputs are typically used in applications such as smart HVAC systems, portable devices, and thermal management solutions.
detailed_results.ground_truth: Key outputs of the BSEC software for the BME690 include Index for Air Quality (IAQ), CO2 equivalent (ppm), and b-VOC equivalent (ppm).
detailed_results.expected_response: The BSEC software for the BME690 provides several key outputs, including an Index for Air Quality (IAQ), bVOC-equivalents (ppm), CO2-equivalents (ppm), Gas scan result (%), and an Intensity level.
expected_contexts: Key parameters for gas sensor: Output data processing: Major direct outputs: Index for Air Quality (IAQ), bVOC- & CO2-equivalents (ppm), Gas scan result (%) & Intensity level
The BSEC provides numerous useful outputs (see Table 20), e.g. an Index for Air Quality (IAQ), bVOC- & CO2-equivalents (ppm) and Gas scan results (%).
BSEC outputs: IAQ (0-500), Static IAQ, CO2 equivalent (ppm), b-VOC equivalent (ppm), TVOC equivalent (ppb).
The IAQ output is an index that can have values between 0 and 500.
The BME AI-Studio tool enables customers to train the BME690 gas scanner on their specific application.

# SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software

Banner's SNAP SIGNAL Configuration Software offers an easy way to configure and demonstrate Banner Modbus devices. Users have full control of device configuration, the ability to visualize device data, and to demonstrate device features. The easy-to-use software provides a variety of tools and works with Banner Modbus devices.

detailed_results.question: What are the different BSEC software power modes for the BME690 gas sensor?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
The BME690 gas sensor features several BSEC (Bosch Software Environmental Cluster) software power modes, which typically include:

1. **Sleep Mode**: The sensor is in a low-power state, consuming minimal energy while not actively measuring.

2. **Idle Mode**: The sensor is ready to take measurements but is not currently active, allowing for quick activation when needed.

3. **Active Mode**: The sensor is fully operational, actively measuring temperature, humidity, pressure, and gas concentrations.

4. **Forced Mode**: The sensor performs a measurement on demand, regardless of the current power mode.

These modes help optimize power consumption based on the application's requirements, allowing for efficient operation in battery-powered devices. For specific details and configurations, refer to the BME690 datasheet or BSEC documentation.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The BME690's BSEC software offers Gas Scan, Ultra-low power (ULP), Low power (LP), and Continuous power modes.
detailed_results.expected_response: The BSEC software for the BME690 gas sensor supports four power modes: Gas Scan mode (scan), Ultra-low power (ULP) mode, Low power (LP) mode, and Continuous (CONT) mode.
expected_contexts: BSEC gas sensor power-modes Table: Standard gas scan mode (scan), Ultra-low power mode (ULP), Low power mode (LP), Continuous mode...
ULP mode is designed for battery-powered and/or frequency-coupled devices...
LP mode that is designed for interactive applications...
Gas Scan mode (scan) is designed for interactive applications where selectivity of traget gases are needed...
Continuous (CONT) mode provides an update rate of 1 Hz and shall only be used short-term...

detailed_results.question: Can the Bosch BME690 gas scanner be customized, and if so, how?
detailed_results.generated_answer:
The Bosch BME690 gas scanner can be customized through its configuration settings, which may include adjusting parameters such as sensor address, baud rate, and communication protocols. Customization can typically be achieved via software interfaces or programming tools provided by Bosch Sensortec. 

To customize the BME690, you would generally follow these steps:

1. **Access the Configuration Interface**: Use the appropriate software or hardware interface to connect to the BME690 sensor.

2. **Set Communication Parameters**: Adjust settings such as baud rate and parity through the COM settings provided in the datasheet. For example, you can set the baud rate using Modbus register values.

3. **Modify Sensor Settings**: Depending on the application, you may need to configure specific parameters related to temperature, humidity, pressure, and gas detection.

4. **Implement AI Features**: If applicable, leverage the AI capabilities of the BME690 for advanced data processing and analysis.

5. **Test and Validate**: After customization, conduct tests to ensure that the sensor operates as expected in your specific application.

For detailed instructions, refer to the BME690 datasheet and any additional documentation provided by Bosch Sensortec.
detailed_results.ground_truth: Yes, the BME690 gas scanner can be customized for specific applications using the BME AI-Studio tool.
detailed_results.expected_response: Yes, the Bosch BME690 gas scanner can be customized with respect to sensitivity, selectivity, data rate, and power consumption using the BME AI-Studio tool, which allows customers to train the sensor for their specific application.
expected_contexts: And the gas scanner can be customized with respect to sensitivity, selectivity, data rate and power consumption as well.
The BME AI-Studio tool enables customers to train the BME690 gas scanner on their specific application...
For customization we recommend to use the BME AI-Studio software with comprehensive documentation.
Customization of gas scanner mode: Number of Classes 2 to 4, Number of temperature steps up to 10.
Same as BME688, the BME690 has a gas scanner function.

detailed_results.ground_truth: Yes, the BME690 has an internal IIR filter that applies to temperature and pressure data only.
detailed_results.expected_response: Yes, the Bosch BME690 features an internal IIR (Infinite Impulse Response) filter. It applies to the temperature and pressure data to suppress short-term fluctuations, but not to the humidity and gas data.

...the humidity and gas values inside the sensor does not fluctuate rapidly and does not require low pass filtering.
When the IIR filter is enabled, the temperature resolution is 20 bit.

detailed_results.question: What is the purpose of the integrated heater in the BME690's gas sensor?
detailed_results.generated_answer: The integrated heater in the BME690's gas sensor is used to enhance the sensor's performance by enabling the detection of various gases. The heater helps to elevate the temperature of the sensor, which can improve the sensitivity and selectivity of gas detection. By heating the sensor, it can facilitate the reaction of gas molecules with the sensing material, leading to more accurate measurements and better response times for detecting specific gases in the environment.
detailed_results.ground_truth: The heater in the BME690 changes the temperature of the gas-sensitive layer to enable classification of different gases.
detailed_results.expected_response: The integrated heater in the Bosch BME690's gas sensor is used to heat the metal oxide gas sensitive layer to various target temperatures (typically 200°C to 400°C). Operating at different temperatures enables the sensor to have different sensitivities, creating a unique 'fingerprint' to help classify different gas compositions.
expected_contexts: Gas sensor heating and measurement: Heating the gas sensor hot plate to a target temperature (typically between 200°C and 400°C)...

Selectivity: Operating the metal oxide layer of the gas sensor at different temperatures enable measuring with different sensitivities and can create a unique fingerprint for numerous gas compositions.
The standard heater profile...consists of 10 heater temperature steps.
Up to 10 different hot plate temperature set points can be configured...
The internal heater control loop operates on the resistance of the heater structure.

detailed_results.ground_truth: The maximum startup time for the BME690 is 2 ms.
